definition: marriage by capture/bride kidnapping
see 搶風|抢风[qiang1 feng1]
to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
to marry/marriage/wedding/to take a wife

sentences.english: It turned out that a number of tribes in ancient China, there is looting marriage customs.
sentences.chinese: 原来，在古代中国的一些部落，有抢婚的习俗。

sentences.english: The marriage by kidnapping was the result of mankind society.
sentences.chinese: 抢婚是人类社会某一历史阶段的产物。

sentences.english: The grabbing-bride ceremony is a rare custom nowadays.
sentences.chinese: 抢婚的风俗现在已经很少见了。

sentences.english: A love match should be at the wishes of both sides, how can they grab a bride?
sentences.chinese: 恋爱婚姻需要男女双方自愿，怎么能抢婚呢？

definition: marriage by capture/bride kidnapping
to flee to avoid an arranged marriage
to break a promise of marriage
bridegroom/groom
disturbing the privacy of bridal room (Chinese custom where guests banter with and play pranks on the newlyweds)
ritual kneeling to heaven and earth by bride and groom in a old-fashioned wedding ceremony/same as 拜天地
to propose marriage
posthumous or ghost marriage (in which at least one of the bride and groom is dead)
throwing the embroidered ball (traditional Zhuang flirting game at festivals)/(fig.) to make overtures/to court
to elope
to get engaged
wedding ceremony/wedding/CL:場|场[chang3]
(of the groom's family) to send a bridal sedan chair 花轎|花轿 to fetch the bride/to send a party to escort the bride to the groom's house
to catch a couple in the act (adultery, illicit sexual relations)
bridesmaid/maid of honor/matron of honor
variant of 訂婚|订婚[ding4 hun1]
